hints_html: The given equality should remind you of a Newton quotient (a derivative). Does the derivative have to be equal to 2 of an arbitrary function?
hints_latex:
The given equality should remind you of a Newton quotient (a
derivative). Does the derivative have to be equal to 2 of an arbitrary
function?
hints_raw: The given equality should remind you of a Newton quotient (a derivative). Does the derivative have to be equal to 2 of an arbitrary function?
question: 1 (d)
sols_html: False: If \(f(x)\) is differentiable at \(x=2\), then by the definition of derivative at a point, we have \(\displaystyle f'(2) = \lim_{h\rightarrow0}\frac{f(2+h)-f(2)}{h}.\) So to paraphrase the statement, we are asking whether \(\displaystyle f'(2) = 2\). Clearly, this does not have to be the case. Consider the example \(\displaystyle f(x)=1\). We have \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is differentiable at \(x=2\) (and everywhere else too). But \(f'(2) = 0\).
sols_latex:
\textbf{False:} If $f(x)$ is differentiable at $x=2$, then by the
definition of derivative at a point, we have
$\displaystyle f'(2) = \lim_{h\rightarrow0}\frac{f(2+h)-f(2)}{h}.$ So to
paraphrase the statement, we are asking whether
$\displaystyle f'(2) = 2$. Clearly, this does not have to be the case.
Consider the example $\displaystyle f(x)=1$. We have
$\displaystyle f(x)$ is differentiable at $x=2$ (and everywhere else
too). But $f'(2) = 0$.
sols_raw: <span>'''False:'''</span> If <math>f(x)</math> is differentiable at <math>x=2</math>, then by the definition of derivative at a point, we have <math>\displaystyle f'(2) = \lim_{h\rightarrow0}\frac{f(2+h)-f(2)}{h}.</math> So to paraphrase the statement, we are asking whether <math>\displaystyle f'(2) = 2</math>. Clearly, this does not have to be the case. Consider the example <math>\displaystyle f(x)=1</math>. We have <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is differentiable at <math>x=2</math> (and everywhere else too). But <math>f'(2) = 0</math>.
statement_html:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

d) If \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is differentiable at x = 2, then \(\lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{f(2 + h) - f(2)}{h} = 2.\)
statement_latex:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is
true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

d) If $\displaystyle f(x)$ is differentiable at x = 2, then
$\lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{f(2 + h) - f(2)}{h} = 2.$
statement_raw:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

<b>d)</b> If <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is differentiable at <i>x = 2</i>, then
<math>
\lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{f(2 + h) - f(2)}{h} = 2.
</math>
